intro: Draba media, commonly known as the common whitlow grass, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically reaches heights of 10–30 centimeters and features basal rosettes of narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers in early spring, which are borne on slender, branching stems. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or arctic environments. Draba media is part of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with characteristic cruciform flowers.
